articles.title: World Hunger Day 2025: Nigerians are hungry
articles.author: Punch Editorial Board
articles.summary: World Hunger Day is on Wednesday. According to Cadre Harmonisé food security report, nearly 31 million Nigerians are expected to face acute food and nutrition insecurity during the June-August lean season. The causes of Nigeria's food crisis are multiple and deeply interwoven. Nigeria is facing severe desertification in the North, coastal erosion and flooding in the South and irregular rainfall patterns. Economic reforms under the Bola Tinubu administration have added further strain to vulnerable households. The government needs to prioritise smallholder farmers and improve access to credit, inputs, and land.

articles.title: Ocean Week Victoria kicks off Sunday
articles.author: Brendan Strain
articles.summary: Ocean Week Victoria is a week-long event in Victoria to raise awareness about the importance of our oceans and the work being done to protect them. Half of the oxygen on earth is produced by life within the oceans. Five per cent of the ocean has been explored by humans.

articles.title: Bengaluru: Two-day exhibition on effect of heat stress in cities
articles.author: Deccan Herald
articles.summary: A two-day exhibition hopes to bring attention to the effects of heat stress caused by rising global temperatures. Purpose, a strategy consultancy and a social movement incubator, is organising the show as part of its People First Cities initiative.

articles.title: Why You Should Worry About How Warm the Oceans Have Become
articles.author: Ayman Rani Ahmed
articles.summary: Warming oceans are reshaping our weather, our cities and the very balance of life on Earth. For anyone passionate about the weather or the natural world, the story of our warming oceans is as gripping as any thriller and it's happening right before our eyes.

articles.title: Earth is heading for 2.7°C warming this century. We may avoid the worst climate scenarios – but the outlook is still dire
articles.summary: Sven Teske is the Research Director, Institute for Sustainable Futures, University of Technology Sydney. He believes humanity has shifted track enough to avert the worst climate future. The worst case scenario of expanded coal use, soaring emissions and a much hotter world is unlikely. Earth is tracking towards around 2.7°C average warming by 2100.

articles.title: Forests are increasingly becoming carbon emitters
articles.author: bne Intelli News
articles.summary: Forests that used to remove carbon from the atmosphere are becoming significant sources of emissions due to record-setting fires in regions like the boreal belt, the Amazon and Australia. Carbon offset schemes should evolve from rewarding reforestation to considering how rising temperatures, water scarcity, and insect outbreaks increase vulnerability. Effective planning must account for regional water cycles, soil resilience and predicted climate extremes, while incorporating fire-prevention tactics.

articles.title: How Climate Alarmists Twist Facts and Words To Suit Their Agenda
articles.author: Principia Scientific
articles.summary: Climate activists twisted the dictionary to support their agenda. They twisted the science and the dictionary, too, as this article points out. It's not just science, it's also the dictionary. It is not just a matter of science, but of the dictionary as well.

articles.title: Skomer Island puffin numbers hit record high despite global fall
articles.author: Elen Davies
articles.summary: 43,626 puffins were counted on Skomer Island off the Pembrokeshire coast this year. Wildlife Trust of South and West Wales (WTSWW) considers it a conservation success story. The island is home to 350,000 breeding pairs of manx shearwaters and thousands of guillemots and razorbills. Puffins are listed as vulnerable to extinction on the IUCN red list.

articles.title: Early & excess: Rain triggers fears of 2018 flood & landslides in Karnataka
articles.author: Manu Aiyappa Kanathanda
articles.summary: There has been 45% excess rainfall in May, which has already claimed nearly a dozen lives. Several rivers are already in spate, isolated landslides have been reported, and infrastructure and crops have suffered damage. The IMD has issued an orange alert for the coastal belt, forecasting continued heavy rainfall and strong winds over the next three to four days.

articles.title: Scientist expresses concern WA government department interfered with rock art report linked to North West Shelf approval process
articles.author: Rhiannon Shine
articles.summary: WA government released the long-awaited results from its ongoing Rock Art Monitoring Program on the Burrup Peninsula, or Murujuga, near Karratha in WA's north. The study is trying to determine whether industrial pollution has degraded Indigenous rock carvings thought to be 40,000 years old. Professor Adrian Baddeley, the report's chief statistician, expressed "grave concern" about the way one of the graphs in the scientific paper had been handled.

articles.title: The BBC's Mark Poynting shows how to spread climate alarm
articles.author: Chris Morrison
articles.summary: Mark Poynting, one of the BBC's top doom-mongering activists, uses the trusted 'scientists say' message to turn a centennial sea level rise of around 30 cm into prose. The BBC story is based on the recent compilation and interpretation of material from a group led by Geography Professor Chris Stokes.

articles.title: Global warming linked to increased cancer risk in women
articles.author: Watauga Democrat
articles.summary: Climate change in the Middle East and North Africa is making breast, ovarian, uterine, and cervical cancer more common and more deadly, according to scientists' research. It's also making it more difficult to detect and treat these cancerous conditions. It is also making them more contagious.

articles.title: Weaponizing Uncertainty: Climate Scientists Admit They Don't Know—Then Demand You Obey Anyway
articles.author: Charles Rotter
articles.summary: Adam Sobel and Kerry Emanuel write an article titled 'Hurricane risk in a changing climate — the role of uncertainty' in Nature. The article is a masterclass in rhetorical misdirection. It's a textbook example of how scientific ambiguity can be turned into policy certainty.

articles.title: 'Underrated': brrr-ave the cold in our top Aussie camping spots this winter
articles.author: Sarah Falson
articles.summary: Winter camping in Australia is an opportunity to don your best wollies and pack your favourite boots and beanie. It's also a great way to get out in spectacular natural settings.    for people who like to explore the natural settings in winter.

articles.title: 'Underrated': brrr-ave the cold in our top Aussie camping spots this winter
articles.author: Sarah Falson
articles.summary: Winter camping in Australia is an opportunity to don your best wollies and pack your favourite boots and beanie. It's also a great way to get out in spectacular natural settings.    for people who like to explore the natural settings in winter.

articles.title: New Study Uncovers How Songbirds Adapt Flight Patterns Across Midwest
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Cornell Lab of Ornithology used weather radar technology to study avian migration patterns in the Corn Belt. The study found that birds increase their flight speed and adjust their flight timing to avoid inhospitable conditions in the agricultural heartland of the United States. Since the 1850s, 76% of native forests and grasslands have been converted into corn monocultures. The scattered inclusion of forest fragments alters the dynamic in subtle yet critical ways.

articles.title: Spring Facts to Lift Your Spirits
articles.author: Ashok Thakur
articles.summary: The spring equinox falls on March 20 in the Northern Hemisphere and on September 22 in the Southern Hemisphere. Many families gain an additional member during this period, making spring officially the season of babies. Many animals, including cattle and sheep, experience increased birth rates during spring. The earliest use of the term 'spring clean' can be traced back to the 1840s.

articles.title: Warming Black Sea may fuel stronger storms in future, study warns
articles.summary: Temperatures in the Black Sea could rise by an average of 4 degrees Celsius by the end of the century under the worst-case climate scenario. The biggest effect of the warming Black Sea will be the intensification of storms, according to Professor Mehmet Ilıcak from Istanbul Technical University's Department of Climate and Marine Sciences.

articles.title: HEADLINE: 'The Guardian is lying about mosquito-borne diseases in the UK.' by Anthony Watts
articles.author: Stephen Heins
articles.summary: No, Climate Change Isn't Behind Britain's Mosquito Fears. The Guardian is lying about mosquito-borne diseases in the UK. England's climate has been suitable for the mosquitoes bearing 'tropical' diseases for centuries. Malaria was endemic in England even during the Little Ice Age. It was largely eradicated in the 20th century with the draining of wetlands and improved housing. The main drivers of disease spread are human movement, infrastructure, sanitation and public health responses.

articles.title: Changes announced for Pennsylvania migratory game bird seasons
articles.author: Rebecca Parsons
articles.summary: Pennsylvania Game Commission announced changes to migratory bird hunting season for 2025-26. The daily bag limit for Canada geese in the Atlantic Population Zone has decreased from three to one, and for northern pintails, there will be a flat daily limit of three. Hunters are encouraged to report any banded birds that they harvest.

articles.title: Studay: Earth's Temperature May Increase by 2.7°C by 2100
articles.author: Rana Atef
articles.summary: The Earth is projected to warm by 2.7°C by the end of this century according to a new study. Since the 2015 Paris Agreement, the world has made progress in cutting CO2 emissions. The EU cut its emissions by over 8% in 2023, and China's CO2 output is now falling for the first time. The U.S. and Australia recorded slight drops, but not enough to stay within the remaining global carbon budget.

articles.title: How many swifts can fit in a chimney? At least 2,400!
articles.summary: A technician with Birds Canada captured more than 2,400 chimney swifts flying into a Fredericton chimney on May 25. The swifts were flying into the chimney from a nearby chimney. The chimney is located in a residential building.

articles.title: Nigeria commits to low-carbon climate-resilient economy
articles.author: Omowumi Samuel
articles.summary: The National Council on Climate Change Secretariat, NCCCS, is collaborating with various partners on the ongoing initiatives geared towards Just-Transition. The Director General, Dr Nkiruka Maduekwe stated this at the National Dialogue on Just Transition held in Abuja, the nation's capital.

articles.title: Amutinu-Salakope Leader Demands Urgent Coastal Protection Amid Tidal Destruction
articles.author: Africa
articles.summary: Tidal waves devastated coastal communities, destroyed homes, flooded critical roads, and displaced residents. The latest surge submerged the Keta-Aflao economic corridor under sand, forcing families to flee with salvaged belongings and leaving students stranded without access to schools. Despite a GH₵2 million budget allocation following former President John Mahama's visit to assess damage, no progress has been reported on promised sea defense walls.

articles.title: Greta Robertson, 95
articles.author: Www.Wydaily.Com Http
articles.summary: Greta Russ Arnau Robertson passed away on May 19, 2025 at the age of 95. She is survived by her daughter Rebecca Farrar, son and daughter-in-law William Arnau and his wife Karen, her sister Catherine Prehn, 9 grandchildren, 14 great-grandchildren and 3 great-great grandchildren, and her daughter Debbie Berry. The funeral services will be held at 2:00 PM on Wednesday, May 28, 2025, at Greenlawn Memorial Park, Shipyard Blvd. and at 3:00 pm at the United Advent Christian Church, 4912 College Rd.

articles.title: Climate change could be driving up cancer rates in women, study finds
articles.author: Ani Freedman
articles.summary: In the U.S., cancer rates are going up, especially for young and middle-aged women. Women under 50 are now almost twice as likely to develop cancer than men of the same age. In 17 Middle Eastern and North African countries most vulnerable to warming temperatures, cancer prevalence and deaths rose in six countries: Qatar, Bahrain, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, and Syria.

articles.title: The American robin returns on time
articles.author: Alaska Native News
articles.summary: American robins have returned to northern Alaska. The population of the American robin increased by about 0.13% per year from 1966 to 2019. Robins live in Alaska and other parts of North America. They are tolerant of humans and their activities. They eat earthworms and other insects.

articles.title: Arsonist set fires at Melbourne Aldi construction site, police say
articles.author: Christie Zizo
articles.summary: Fires were set in the construction area for an Aldi grocery store on East Eau Gallie Boulevard in Melbourne, Florida, on Sunday morning. A construction worker saw one of the fires and called 911, but the suspect was able to escape. The Melbourne Fire Department put out the fires, which caused damage estimated to cost over $100,000. Police are also looking for a robbery suspect who attacked an employee at Texas Roadhouse.

articles.title: As glaciers melt in Alaska and Canada, fishing and mining advocates alike see opportunity
articles.author: Alaska Public Media
articles.summary: As climate change raises global temperatures, glaciers are retreating in Alaska and Canada. There could be 4,000 miles of new salmon streams created by the end of the century. Mining companies want to take advantage of what's left behind when glaciers retreat. Some Alaskans are concerned about the impact of mines on their communities.

articles.title: Sarawak To Learn From Global Best Practices To Tackle Climate Change Impact On Agriculture
articles.author: BERNAMA
articles.summary: Sarawak must look to international best practices to mitigate the growing impact of climate change on its agriculture sector, says state Minister of Food Industry, Commodity and Regional Development, Datuk Seri Dr Stephen Rundi Utom. He was speaking at the Sarawak State Legislative Assembly today.

articles.title: State records 590 heatwave days in 35 yrs
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Jharkhand recorded a 300% rise in the number of annual heatwave days in the past 35 years, according to a report by the Center for Environment and Energy Development (CEED) on Tuesday. The report is titled 'Scorching reality — Rising heatwave in India'.

articles.title: Climate and weather scientists are joining the anti-Trump resistance in the most ‘scientist-iest' way
articles.author: Andrew Freedman
articles.summary: Starting Wednesday at 1 p.m. ET and lasting for 100 straight hours, climate and weather specialists will spend 15 minutes each talking about their work and why it is so valuable for the American people. Their goal is to call attention to the impacts of cuts to federal agencies like the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, NASA and the Department of Energy. It is also timed to mark the end of NASA's longstanding lease at Columbia University.

articles.title: VIDEO: A pigeon seeks refuge from extreme heat at a mall in Dubai
articles.author: gulftoday
articles.summary: The highest temperature in Sweihan, Al Ain, was 51.6 degrees Celsius on Saturday. The highest ever temperature recorded in the UAE since documentation began in 2003 was reported at 52C on Abu Dhabi's Al Yasat Island in 2010. The UAE is a top global oil exporter and is vulnerable to climate change.

articles.title: Future Royal Family Member Relocates to Australia for Studies
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Princess Ingrid Alexandra of Norway is moving to Australia to study at the University of Sydney. She will start her Bachelor of Arts program in August and focus on international relations and political economy. Alexandra is the second in line to the Norwegian throne after her father, Crown Prince Haakon.

articles.title: Weather Warning: Cold front set to impact western regions, with damaging winds and rain
articles.author: Wendy Dondolo
articles.summary: A powerful cold front is expected to impact several provinces starting from Wednesday, May 28. The SAWS has issued a Level 2 warning for damaging winds over the Western Cape and Northern Cape provinces. Offshore, small vessels and personal watercraft are at increased risk due to the choppy seas and strong winds. Maximum temperatures not exceeding 16 degrees are expected for Cape Town, from Wednesday through the weekend, with lows of around 14 degrees.

articles.title: Cold front alert: Icy cold weather to sweep across parts of SA, bringing gusty winds and scattered showers
articles.author: Wendy Dondolo
articles.summary: A powerful cold front is expected to impact several provinces starting from Wednesday, May 28. The SAWS has issued a Level 2 warning for damaging winds over the Western Cape and Northern Cape provinces. Offshore, small vessels and personal watercraft are at increased risk due to the choppy seas and strong winds. Maximum temperatures not exceeding 16 degrees are expected for Cape Town, from Wednesday through the weekend, with lows of around 14 degrees.

articles.title: Climate impact worries and warnings
articles.author: Meena Janardhan
articles.summary: As the climate warms, extreme weather events are becoming more frequent and severe across India. Half of Indians are worried about extinctions of plant and animal species, severe heat waves, agricultural pests and diseases, droughts and water shortages, and severe air pollution. A significant proportion of people in India have never heard of global warming.

articles.title: Penguin Poop Helps Drive Cloud Formation Over Antarctica, According to a New Study
articles.author: Sara Hashemi
articles.summary: Ammonia from Adélie penguin guano can play a significant role in cloud formation over Antarctica. The guano's byproducts accelerated the formation of clouds by 10,000 times. The exact consequences of these clouds are unknown, but they could reduce the impacts of climate change by regulating surface temperatures.

articles.title: Earth is heading for 2.7°C warming this century. We may avoid the worst climate scenarios – but the outlook is still dire
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: In late 2015, nations agreed through the Paris Agreement to try to hold warming well under 2°C and ideally to 1.5°C. Earth is tracking towards 2.7°C average warming by 2100. Global greenhouse gas emissions have risen since industrialisation began around 1850. The world is feeling the effects.

articles.title: Sundrea area sets new temperature record for May 26
articles.author: Sheldon Spackman
articles.summary: Sundre area sets new temperature record for May 26 at 27.7 degrees Celsius, beating the previous record of 22.7 degree Celsius set in 2018. The daily maximum temperature record was set in the Sundre area on Monday. Records have been kept in this area since 1993.

articles.title: Photos: Over 100 White-faced Ibis gather at Broadview
articles.author: Gazette staff
articles.summary: A flock of over 100 White-faced Ibis shore birds feed in flooded wheat fields near Broadview over the holiday weekend. The birds are common in the southeastern U.S., South Africa and Asia and are common on the shore in South America and Asia.

articles.title: Quokkas in Australia become viral sensations
articles.author: Cbs News
articles.summary: The quokka is the world's happiest animal. It's forbidden to touch quokkas and they even have the right of way on roads. Quokkas have no natural predators, so they're fearless and friendly with people. Celebrities try to copy their selfies.

articles.title: Marcos encourages contribution to Loss and Damage Fund
articles.author: Manila Bulletin
articles.summary: Marcos encourages ASEAN to contribute to the Fund for Responding to Loss and Damage. He stressed that climate change is one of the most defining challenges of our time. Marcos also stressed the importance of freedom of navigation in the South China Sea and Arabian Sea. He expressed grave concern over Israel's military operations in Gaza.

articles.title: Heat record set in Milk River on Monday
articles.author: David Opinko
articles.summary: Milk River set a new heat record on Monday, May 26, 2025. The mercury hit 26.8 degrees Celsius in Milk River on Monday. Lethbridge's high was 30 degrees. The weather forecaster is calling for high 20s and low 30s for most of this week in Lethbridge. Sunday and Monday could see cooler temperatures with rain.

articles.title: Global warming linked to increased cancer risk in women
articles.author: Stephen Beech
articles.summary: Women's cancer risk is being driven up by global warming, according to new research. Stephen Beech wrote the research for the Daily Mail.       .   for e-mail newsletters. For more information, visit: http://www.dailymail.co.uk/newsletters.

articles.title: Global warming linked to increased cancer risk in women
articles.author: Stephen Beech
articles.summary: Women's cancer risk is being driven up by global warming, according to new research, says Stephen Beech of Talker.news.    .      - BLOX Digital Content Exchange is part of the BLOX digital content exchange.

articles.title: Global warming linked to increased cancer risk in women
articles.author: Stephen Beech
articles.summary: Temperatures have been linked to an increased risk of breast, ovarian, uterine, and cervical cancers in the Middle East and North Africa. Cancer prevalence and deaths rose in only six countries: Qatar, Bahrain, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, and Syria.

articles.title: Maritime ports advised to hoist local signal 3
articles.author: UNB
articles.summary: Chattogram, Cox's Bazar, Mongla and Payra have been advised to keep hoisted local cautionary signal No 3 as a low-pressure area has been formed over the northwest Bay and adjoining area. All fishing boats and trawlers over North Bay are advised to remain close to the coast and proceed with caution until further notice.

articles.title: Meet the quokkas: Australia's happy, viral sensations attract tourists that fund conservation efforts
articles.author: Holly
articles.summary: Quokkas are cousins of the kangaroo. They live on Rottnest Island near Australia's west coast in the Indian Ocean. Around 10,000 quokkas live there and have become a popular tourist attraction. Celebrities like Roger Federer, Margot Robbie and Logan Paul have taken selfies with them. Quokkas have no natural predators and are friendly with humans.

articles.title: Several languages on verge of extinction due to climate change
articles.summary: There are 197 endangered languages in India, including Angika, Bajjika, Surajpuri, and Tharu. Climate change and environmental degradation have led to language loss in various parts of Bihar. The young generation prefers to speak Hindi and English instead of their native languages.

articles.title: Hurricane Season 2025
articles.author: TCPalm
articles.summary: NOAA predicts at least three hurricanes this season and three major hurricanes in the 2025 hurricane season. The hurricane off-season gets shorter every year, but the longer you've been alive, the longer the hurricane season gets shorter, so it's not surprising that NOAA predicts more hurricanes this year.

articles.title: Velim farmer blames govt inaction as rain destroys crops
articles.author: Herald Team
articles.summary: Guirdolina Fernandes, a farmer from Velim, is frustrated by the lack of action by the Panchayat and government in repairing the broken bundhs in her village. The bundhs are crucial for protecting agricultural fields from flooding, yet they have been left unrepaired for months. The consequences have been devastating for the farming community, with many losing their main source of income.

articles.title: Crop loss worth ₹4.44 crore in Kannur district as monsoon wreaks havoc
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: A week of heavy rain and strong winds has caused crop damage worth ₹4.44 crore in Kannur. The widespread damage affected 101.47 hectares of farmland, impacting 4.619 farmers. Peravoor and Payyannur blocks bore the brunt, recording losses worth $95.59 lakh and $92.08 lakh respectively. Banana cultivation suffered the most, with damage over 34.08 hectares estimated at $2.39 crore. Rubber plantations also sustained heavy losses.

articles.title: NASA satellites show Antarctica has gained ice despite rising global temperatures. How is that possible?
articles.author: Space
articles.summary: Antarctica has gained ice, according to NASA satellite data. Scientists say it's a temporary anomaly and not an indication that global warming has reversed. It's not a sign of a warming planet, they say, but of an abrupt change in the climate.

articles.title: Uganda: Fires Fuel Record Global Forest Loss in 2024
articles.author: Ronald Musoke
articles.summary: In 2024, forest loss around the world surged to a record high thanks to a calamitous rise in fires. For the first time on record, fires were the leading cause of tropical primary forest loss, accounting for nearly 50% of all destruction. Fires emitted 4.1 gigatons of greenhouse gas emissions. Brazil, the country with the largest area of tropical forest, accounted for 42% of the total forest loss in 2024.

articles.title: Women at higher risk of four cancers because of weather
articles.summary: Temperatures have been linked to an increased risk of breast, ovarian, uterine, and cervical cancers in the Middle East and North Africa. Scientists found that the rise in rates is "small but statistically significant" and suggests a notable increase in cancer risk and fatalities over time.

articles.title: Hurricane season begins June 1. This Florida emergency official reveals what keeps him up at night
articles.author: Associated Press
articles.summary: Monroe County, Florida has a new emergency operations center and a new seawater desalination water treatment plant for the upcoming hurricane season. The county relies on surveillance flights from hurricane-hunting aircraft from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration for information about how to prepare. Hurricane Irma destroyed around 1,180 homes and damaged another 3,000 in the Florida Keys.

articles.title: Earth is heading for 2.7°C warming this century—we may avoid the worst climate scenarios, but the outlook is dire
articles.author: Sven Teske
articles.summary: The United States is withdrawing from the Paris Agreement on climate change. The worst-case scenario of expanded coal use, soaring emissions and a much hotter world is vanishingly unlikely. The Earth is tracking towards around 2.7°C average warming by 2100. Global greenhouse gas emissions have risen since industrialization began around 1850. Europe's net emissions are 37% below 1990 levels, while the region's GDP grew 68%. The EU remains on track to reach its goal of reducing emissions by 55% by 2030. Australia's emissions fell by 0.6% last year. China is cutting its emissions.

articles.title: Fire weather days surge in Arizona
articles.author: Jessica Boehm
articles.summary: The number of fire weather days in Arizona rose by 30-plus days on average between 1973 and 2024. South Central Arizona and Southeastern Arizona saw the biggest increases. Extreme wildfire events more than doubled in frequency and magnitude globally over the past two decades. More than half of Phoenix properties have some risk associated with a wildfire in the next 30 years. Arizona's most destructive fires have historically occurred in wooded areas away from major metros.

articles.title: Chesapeake Bay crab numbers drop again
articles.author: Dave Ress
articles.summary: Chesapeake Bay blue crab populations fell again, hitting the second-lowest number since Virginia and Maryland marine scientists began counting in 1990. Blue crab numbers in the bay fell to 238 million from last year's 317 million. It's the fifth year in a row that the crab population is below averages tallied since 1990. The number of juvenile crabs fell to 103 million from 138 million and the number of females mature enough to reproduce fell to 108 million from 133 million.

articles.title: Ancient Town And Its Manuscripts Face Ravages Of The Sahara
articles.author: ETV Bharat
articles.summary: Oualata is one of a UNESCO-listed quartet of ancient, fortified towns or "ksour" in the Mauritanian desert. Oualata's population has been dwindling as residents move away in search of jobs, leaving nobody to maintain the historic buildings. The family library has 223 manuscripts, the oldest of which dates to the 14th century.

articles.title: Govt ready for hurricane season, committed to ongoing projects in Dominica: PM Skerrit
articles.author: Monica Walker
articles.summary: PM Roosevelt Skerrit will visit Calibishie on Wednesday to discuss ways to minimize future impacts of the recent flooding. He urges citizens to prepare for the upcoming hurricane season. The Dominica Labour Party's 70th anniversary celebrations will continue on June 1st.

articles.title: From Floods to Fires: Cisco Is Investing in Technologies That Make Communities More Resilient
articles.summary: In 2024, global natural disasters resulted in $368 billion in economic losses, with 60% of these losses uninsured. By 2050, climate-intensified natural disasters could lead to $12.5 trillion in global economic losses. Corporate exposure to climate risks is expected to triple by mid-century, with over $1.14 trillion in market value at risk for companies listed on major global exchanges. Global revenues from climate adaptation solutions are expected to grow from $1 trillion today to $4 trillion by 2050, while the investment opportunity could soar from $2 trillion to $9 trillion. Cisco Foundation's Regenerative Future Fund strategically invests in innovative technologies to help communities adapt, respond to,

articles.title: Coastal Ratepayers United - Latest News [Page 1]
articles.author: Scoop Infopages
articles.summary: Kapiti Coast District Council has uploaded the Waikato University De Lange research and accompanying maps onto its website. Coastal property groups are recommending the government update its faulty advice to local authorities on sea level rise. Coastal Ratepayers' United reminds the Council about its statutory obligations to complete the coastal hazard survey.

articles.title: Rising heatwaves putting pregnancies at risk
articles.author: Tribune News Service
articles.summary: In 222 out of 247 countries and territories, climate change has at least doubled the annual number of pregnancy heat-risk days for pregnant people. In the most severely affected areas, all of the extreme heat days experienced over the past five years were attributed to human-caused climate change.

articles.title: When Antarctica Grows Ice and Science Gets Cold Feet
articles.author: David Manney
articles.summary: Antarctica has gained ice mass between 2021 and 2023, despite what every climate model said would happen. Dr. Roy Spencer, a climatologist and former NASA scientist, has long argued that climate models consistently run hot, meaning they predict significantly more warming than we actually observe.

articles.title: China, Pacific Island nations set new South-South cooperation model
articles.author: Zhu Xuan
articles.summary: Zhu Xuan is a researcher at the Research Center for Pacific Island Countries (RCPIC) of Liaocheng University in east China's Shandong Province. China has established a series of cooperation mechanisms aimed at supporting sustainable development in the PICs since 2021. Pacific Island Islands (PICs) are some of the most vulnerable states in the world amid accelerating climate change. Strengthening climate resilience and protecting the lives and livelihoods of residents are top priorities for these nations. China supports PIC's development through cooperation in climate change, rural development, education, and other key areas.

articles.title: ⚡Australia: Dust Storms Sweep Across Country as Experts Warn of Growing Climate Extremes
articles.summary: A vast dust storm moving across Australia has shrouded Sydney in a dense haze, sparking health alerts and underscoring the growing impact of climate extremes nationwide. The storm is moving across the country at a high speed.       in the direction of Sydney.

articles.title: Study links global warming to rising cancers among women
articles.author: International Business Times
articles.summary: As temperatures rise, cancer mortality among women also rises, especially for ovarian and breast cancers, according to the Frontiers in Public Health study published on Tuesday. The study found its association with increasing global warming conditions, which is linked to cancer cases in women.

articles.title: How Ancient Meteor Showers May Have Triggered Mini-Extinctions
articles.author: Awais Khan
articles.summary: Earth's history is punctuated by catastrophic events that have dramatically altered the course of life on our planet. The dinosaur-killing asteroid impact 66 million years ago stands as the most famous extinction event linked to cosmic bombardment. Scientists believe there may have been many smaller, but still significant "mini-extinctions" triggered by meteor showers throughout Earth's tumultuous past.

articles.title: ‘Bigger by the day': Paul Murray breaks down Australia's population surge
articles.summary: Paul Murray says Australia is getting bigger by the day. Australia has grown by 11 million people in the best part of 30 years. There are now 11 million more mouths to feed and people to find housing for. Australia is set to grow.

articles.title: Dust storms sweep across Australia as experts warn of growing climate extremes
articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: A vast dust storm moving across Australia has shrouded Sydney in a dense haze, sparking health alerts and underscoring the growing impact of climate extremes nationwide. New South Wales (NSW) Health on Tuesday said the effects of climate change are only exacerbating this process.

articles.title: Kilifi Woman Survives 16-Hour Nightmare as Two Captains Drown at Sea
articles.summary: Two fishermen from Mnarani village in Kilifi County died in a deep-sea fishing accident on May 23. Aisha Mohamed, a single mother of four, and Hatari Kitsao, the co-captain of the ill-fated boat, survived the ordeal. Mohamed has issued a public appeal, urging fellow fishers to heed warnings and avoid setting sail in dangerous conditions.

articles.title: Climate Change—Impact on Tribal Communities and their Response
articles.summary: Tribal communities are often identified to be among the more vulnerable communities to climate change. Bharat Dogra is Honorary Convener of Save Earth for Children's 2071 Day. He believes that tribal communities are well-endowed in several respects which have a new relevance in terms of climate change adaptation and resilience.

articles.title: Tracking Kerala's monsoon: updates, warnings and impact
articles.summary: Kerala is experiencing an early and intense monsoon this year, raising questions about the state's preparedness and the impact of climate change on weather patterns. A panel of experts will discuss the science behind the early onset of the monsoon and assess Kerala's disaster management systems.

articles.title: Why spring allergies feel worse this year
articles.author: Patricia D'Cunha
articles.summary: Scientists say seasonal allergies are getting worse around the world due to climate change. Kris McCusker speaks to BBC science and features journalist, Amanda Ruggeri, about the in-depth piece she wrote on the issue and how allergy sufferers can improve their circumstances.

articles.title: Why spring allergies feel worse this year
articles.author: Patricia D'Cunha
articles.summary: Scientists say seasonal allergies are getting worse around the world due to climate change. Kris McCusker speaks to BBC science and features journalist, Amanda Ruggeri, about the in-depth piece she wrote on the issue and how allergy sufferers can improve their circumstances.

articles.title: Why spring allergies feel worse this year
articles.author: Patricia D'Cunha
articles.summary: Scientists say seasonal allergies are getting worse around the world due to climate change. Kris McCusker speaks to BBC science and features journalist, Amanda Ruggeri, about the in-depth piece she wrote on the issue and how allergy sufferers can improve their circumstances.

articles.title: Why spring allergies feel worse this year
articles.author: Patricia D'Cunha
articles.summary: Scientists say seasonal allergies are getting worse around the world due to climate change. Kris McCusker speaks to BBC science and features journalist, Amanda Ruggeri, about the in-depth piece she wrote on the issue and how allergy sufferers can improve their circumstances.

articles.title: Coastal residents face profound dilemma about future of community as property threat looms: 'Something had to be done'
articles.author: Timothy McGill
articles.summary: Rising seas are threatening the serenity of Beaufort, North Carolina's fourth-oldest town. Keith Rittmaster had to raise his home 10 feet to avoid frequent flooding. It cost him $80,000, nearly 10 times the amount he paid for the house 43 years ago.

articles.title: Global warming could be making cancer among women more common
articles.summary: There is a rise in the prevalence and death rates of breast, ovarian, uterine, and cervical cancers due to climate change. Cancer death rates increased by 171-332 per one lakh people for each degree of temperature rise. The biggest rise was in ovarian cancer cases and the smallest in cervical cancer.

articles.title: 2025 Hurricane Forecast and Steel Industry Uncertainty
articles.author: prowwler
articles.summary: NOAA is predicting an above-normal 2025 Atlantic hurricane season. FEMA has denied North Carolina's request for extended relief funding related to Hurricane Helene. A new audit highlighting the state's disaster-response failures is set to be released on July 1. The North Carolina Supreme Court has ruled that State Auditor Jessica Holmes Boliek can maintain her appointments to the state elections board.

articles.title: Ring of Fire road report highlights impacts to Ontario First Nation
articles.author: Carl Meyer
articles.summary: A new report on a proposed road to Ontario's remote Ring of Fire says it could improve quality of life for many people, but also affect cultural traditions and impact the environment and animals. Construction on the 184-kilometre road to the remote Anishinaabe community northeast of Thunder Bay, Ont., is expected to cost $1.3 billion. The draft report includes hundreds of recommendations on how to protect the vast peatlands in the region and the significant carbon they store. The area studied for the Marten Falls road overlaps four provincial and three federal ranges for caribou, a species at risk. The report is part of both federal and provincial environmental and impact assessments

articles.title: Scientists uncover troubling ocean trend that could have dangerous consequences: 'Action is needed'
articles.author: Zachary Craley
articles.summary: Half of the marine heat waves that have occurred since 2000 would not have happened without the rise in global temperatures. The global average has risen to nearly 50 days of extreme heat per year. The extra heat increases the duration of heat waves in tropical regions where it's already warm. Warm water at the surface fuels more intense hurricanes. Heat waves can bleach coral reefs and kill kelp forests.

articles.title: Is climate change a threat? It depends, says Elon Musk's AI chatbot.
articles.author: Scott Waldman
articles.summary: Grok, the AI chatbot program developed by xAI, the company led by Elon Musk, has changed its stance on global warming. It is now on its third iteration after first launching in 2023. The new version is promoting fringe climate viewpoints in a way it hasn't done before.

articles.title: What's One Way to Help Preserve the Antarctic Climate? Penguin Poop.
articles.author: Bob Berwyn
articles.summary: Ammonia from penguin guano in Antarctica is an important source of ammonia aerosol particles that drive the formation and persistence of low clouds. Low clouds cool the climate by reflecting some incoming sunlight back to space. Scientists don't know how penguins will react to human-caused warming of the atmosphere and oceans.

articles.title: Riley Laychuk's Manitoba forecast for Tuesday, May 27, 2025
articles.summary: There are still air quality concerns due to wildfires in northern Manitoba. Temperatures remain above seasonal and could reach 30 C in some places.    in some locations.  In others, the temperature could reach as high as 30 C. in some parts of the province.

articles.title: BIRDWATCH: The decline of the wild birds
articles.author: Ken Hooles
articles.summary: The bird species has been declining over the past few years. The most prolific killers of birds are feral and domestic cats. The second well known cause is window collisions, both at our homes and at office towers around the world. Some companies pay people to gather the dead birds at the base of these skyscrapers in the early morning prior to the arrival of the occupants.

articles.title: BIRDWATCH: The decline of the wild birds
articles.author: Ken Hooles
articles.summary: Ken Hooles wrote an article about the decline of the birds in North America. He republishes it for those who missed it. According to nature articles, over three billion birds have died in the last few years. Predators, cats, window collisions and wind turbines are some of the main reasons for this decline. Plastics and microplastics in the water and oceans are also a problem for aquatic birds.

articles.title: Along Ghana's vanishing coast, climate change swallows history, homes
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Ghana's coast is being eroded by climate change, rising sea levels and human activity. Villages are vanishing, and with them, centuries-old heritage. Fort Prinzenstein, once a Danish slave fort and now a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is among the most threatened sites on Ghana's coast.

articles.title: Climate Costs: Heat & Cold Exposure Hits Aussie Workforce
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Exposure to heat and cold is costing Australian workers and employers an estimated $94 million a year. Heat-related occupational injuries and illnesses (OIIs) are projected to rise more than 25 per cent by 2050. Researchers from Charles Darwin University, the University of Adelaide and Monash University analysed more than 2.3 million workplace injury claims across all capital cities.

articles.title: Global warming 'increasing cancer risk for women in Middle East'
articles.author: Paul Carey
articles.summary: There is a significant increase in cancer cases among women in the Middle East and North Africa due to global warming, according to a study by the American University in Cairo. The study looked at 17 Middle Eastern and North African countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, Libya, Morocco, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Syria, Tunisia, United Arab Emirates and Palestine. Ovarian cancer cases rose the most and breast cancer cases the least.

articles.title: Public beaches in Mombasa re-opened after three-day closure
articles.author: BRIAN ORUTA
articles.summary: Public beaches in Mombasa County have reopened after a three-day closure due to adverse weather conditions, including strong winds and high waves. A temporary ban on construction activities in the county has also been lifted. The beaches will remain closed on Monday if the weather does not improve.

articles.title: Medical Experts Alert to Connection Between Cancer and Issue Trump Labels a Hoax
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Scientists from the American University in Cairo studied the incidence of breast, cervical, ovarian, and uterine cancers across 17 Middle Eastern nations. They found that each 1.8 degrees Celsius rise in temperature increases cancer cases by as much as 280 per 100,000 people. Cancer deaths from all four cancers on average rose by 171 to 332 deaths per 100 people for each degree of temperature rise. The greatest rise in deaths was in ovarian cancer at 332, and the smallest was in cervical cancer at 171.

articles.title: Rising Temperatures Linked to Increased Female Cancer Cases in MENA
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Rising temperatures are linked to higher rates of female cancer cases and deaths in the Middle East and North Africa. The American University in Cairo studied cancer data from 1998 to 2019 and found a statistically significant increase in both prevalence and mortality of cancers such as ovarian, breast, and uterine corresponding to each degree Celsius rise in temperature.

articles.title: Florida needs to streamline and bolster hurricane recovery
articles.author: Nick Diceglie
articles.summary: Nick DiCeglie's hometown of Indian Rocks Beach was hit hard by Hurricanes Milton and Helene. He filed Senate Bill 180 to address statewide hurricane recovery, response and resiliency and to streamline permitting resources and rebuilding guidelines. It prohibits increased permitting or inspection fees for 180 days after a hurricane or natural disaster.

articles.title: Five Hottest Places Worldwide You Might Want To Think Twice About
articles.author: jamiecrow2
articles.summary: Some places on Earth are so hot that visiting them could be dangerous. Death Valley, California, holds the title for the highest air temperature ever recorded on Earth. Dasht-e Lut, Iran is often the hottest place on Earth by surface temperature thanks to its vast salt flats and black sand. Al-Aziziyah, Libya is one of the most brutally hot inhabited regions in the world. Dallol, Ethiopia is the hottest inhabited place by average annual temperature.

articles.title: Mombasa Opens Public Beaches After 5-Day Closure With Strict Conditions
articles.author: Walter Ngano
articles.summary: Public beaches in Mombasa are now open for public access and recreational use. On Friday, May 23, Governor Abdulswamad Sherrif Nassir had ordered the closure of the beaches for two days. The orders were based on an advisory from the Kenya Meteorological Department.

articles.title: Shift in rain patterns, weather big concern as climate change hits India
articles.summary: India is one of the most vulnerable countries to climate change impacts. The India Heat Summit 2025 is deliberating on the issue of rising temperatures and shared solutions. The deliberation is also focusing on issues related to unseasonal rainfall and the very frequent heavy rainfall occurring in the western parts of India.

articles.title: Naval, fishing communities advised not to venture into sea until further notice
articles.author: AJITH SIRIWARDANA
articles.summary: Naval and fishing communities advised not to venture into the sea areas off the coast extending from Chilaw to Kankesanthurai via Puttalam and Mannar and from Galle to Pottuvil via Hambanthota until further notice due to the effect of the active southwest monsoon weather conditions.

articles.title: Call for sanctions on Israel over Gaza food blockade
articles.author: Dominic Giannini
articles.summary: A former cabinet minister is urging Australia to sanction Israel for blocking food from people in Gaza. He is ramping up pressure on Labor ahead of an international conference aimed at advancing Palestinian statehood.    .   i   in this context  in which Israel blocks food from Gaza.

articles.title: Call for sanctions on Israel over Gaza food blockade
articles.author: Dominic Giannini
articles.summary: A former cabinet minister is urging Australia to sanction Israel for blocking food from people in Gaza. He is ramping up pressure on Labor ahead of an international conference aimed at advancing Palestinian statehood.    .   i   in this context  in which Israel blocks food from Gaza.

articles.title: Trump's Greenland Bid: A Failed Strategy? – Archyde: Latest World News, Economy, Entertainment, Health, Technology & Sports Updates
articles.author: archyde
articles.summary: Alaska is the linchpin for U.S. interests in the high north and the key to navigating a complex geopolitical landscape. The Bering Strait is a chokepoint for access to the Arctic Ocean. Russia and China are actively expanding their presence in the Arctic. The United States cannot secure the Arctic alone. NATO allies offer expertise in polar operations.

articles.title: Odisha on High Alert: SRC Directs District Collectors to Gear Up for Adverse Weather
articles.author: Itishree Sethy
articles.summary: The India Meteorological Department (IMD) forecasts the formation of a low-pressure area over the Bay of Bengal. The development could lead to significant rainfall and thunderstorms across various regions of Odisha. The SRC has instructed officials in districts under orange and yellow warnings to keep emergency response mechanisms ready. Fishermen have been advised to avoid venturing into the sea, while residents are urged to take necessary precautions to protect themselves.

articles.title: World Bank Report Highlights Importance of Social Protection Response in Strengthening Mongolian Households' Resilience to Climate and Economic Shocks
articles.summary: Both urban and rural areas of Mongolia are highly vulnerable to climate shocks such as dzud, floods, and other disaster risks. The dz Dud phenomenon poses a severe threat to livestock and the economic stability of herding families. Vulnerable populations will bear the brunt of these impacts. The World Bank recommends leveraging social protection to boost the adaptive capacity of Mongolian households, including herders.

articles.title: Woodside chief Meg O'Neill accuses young Aussies of being hypocritical while waging war on fossil fuels
articles.summary: Meg O'Neill accuses young Aussies of being hypocritical while waging war on fossil fuels. She claims they are too concerned about the environment to be concerned about climate change. She is referring to young people in Australia who are concerned about fossil fuels, not about environment.

articles.title: Big midnight rush on beaches in UAE; Expatriates join new trend
articles.author: Keralakaumudi Daily
articles.summary: Temperatures in the UAE this week reached 51.6 degrees Celsius. The previous record was 50.2 degrees Celsius in May 2009. People are making changes in their routine plans to adjust to the torrid weather. People venture out of their homes only during the night when the climate is relatively cooler.

articles.title: Masters of survival: Nature's top adaptors
articles.author: Siddhartha Jana
articles.summary: Emperor Penguins huddle in rotating groups to share warmth in -40°C winters. They rely on collective effort to endure the harsh climate. The penguins have to work as a team to survive in this harsh climate, which is caused by climate change.

articles.title: Revealed: The insane salary Aussies now need to buy a home in Sydney
articles.author: MAX ALDRED
articles.summary: Sydney's median house price is now worth more than 13 times the average income. The average Australian salary is $103,000, while a median home price is nearly $1.34 million. The median house in Melbourne is 8.4 times the salary, while in Canberra it's 9.0 times. Darwin has the most affordable houses with prices at 5.8 times the income.

articles.title: Israeli philanthropists, a rare breed, coalesce to fund carbon-slashing projects
articles.author: Sue Surkes
articles.summary: In March, the World Meteorological Organization released its 'State of the Global Climate' report, confirming that 2024 was the warmest year in the 175-year observational record. In Israel, average temperatures for the period 2014 to 2024 were 1.8°C (3.2°F) higher than the period 1950 to 1979. The amount of carbon in the atmosphere last year, just from energy, was twice that of pre-industrial levels. Doris Arkin, who chairs the Israeli Climate Action Fund (PAI), is trying to help Israel reach its climate goals.

articles.title: Europe's dry spring raises fears for wheat and barley harvests
articles.author: Celia Bergin
articles.summary: Dry weather has parched Europe's farms after an unusually dry spring. It follows a winter marked by long periods of low rain and snowfall in key crop-producing regions. Total precipitation in Europe from February through April was below long-term averages, according to the Climate Change Institute.

articles.title: From Scranton to New Bern: Southpaws' 'Rob' Jacobs embracing local community
articles.author: Wayne Dzubak The Sun Journal
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene devastated Western North Carolina in late September of 2024. A utility baseball player from Scranton, PA was living there at the time and was affected by Helene's effects on his life and career. He is now a professional baseball player.

articles.title: Global Baseline Set for Drought Impact Monitoring
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The World Meteorological Organization has released a report "Drought Impact Monitoring: Baseline Review of Practices". The report was released under the banner of the Integrated Drought Management Programme (IDMP) - joint WMO and the Global Water Partnership (GWP). This work is part of WMO's commitment to building global resilience to drought and other hydrometeorological extremes.

articles.title: Marcos asks oil-rich Arab nations for contributions to Loss and Damage Fund
articles.author: Anna Felicia Bajo
articles.summary: Philippine President Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos Jr. asked oil-rich Arab countries for contributions to the Loss and Damage Fund. The member states of the GCC include Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates. The Fund is intended to provide financial assistance to vulnerable countries dealing with the devastating effects of climate change.

articles.title: Women at higher risk of four cancers because of weather
articles.author: Neil Shaw Assistant Editor
articles.summary: Temperatures have been linked to an increased risk of breast, ovarian, uterine, and cervical cancers in the Middle East and North Africa. The prevalence of the different cancers rose by 173 to 280 cases per 100,000 people for every additional degree Celsius. Ovarian cancer cases rose most and breast cancer cases the least.

articles.title: Dry heat to torrential rain - why Scotland is experiencing 'weather whiplash'
articles.author: Christopher Blanchett
articles.summary: After weeks of dry, sunny conditions in Scotland, torrential downpours over the bank holiday weekend marked a sudden change in weather. March and April were far drier than normal, with May seeing only 4% of the normal rainfall by the middle of the month. The switch is driven by a warming world speeding up the water cycle and allowing the atmosphere to hold more water. The dry spring has been a boon for business at the Cheesy Toast Shack on the East Sands of St Andrews.

articles.title: Greece's Summer Climate Outlook: Rising Temperatures and Climate Change Concerns
articles.author: Kowalenko Charlie
articles.summary: Kostas Lagouvardos, Research Director at the National Observatory of Athens, has warned that Greece is likely to experience another summer with temperatures exceeding seasonal norms. This trend aligns with a decade-long increase in the frequency and intensity of prolonged heatwaves. Seasonal forecasts indicate that June, July, and August will see above-average temperatures across much of Europe.

articles.title: Doctors sound alarm over link between cancer explosion and crisis Trump calls a hoax
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: Researchers in Egypt analyzed the rates of breast, cervical, ovarian, uterine, and uterine cancers in 17 Middle Eastern countries and compared them to rising global warming. They found that global warming could be fueling the growing rates of cancer in women there.

articles.title: 59% in Northern Ireland believe human activity is primary cause of climate change
articles.author: Jonathan Mccambridge
articles.summary: Less than 60% of people in Northern Ireland believe that human activity is the primary cause of climate change, according to the Northern Ireland Life and Times (NILT) survey. This is one of the lowest levels of belief in Europe, placing Northern Ireland just above Slovakia and Lithuania, and below the UK average of 90% and 88% in Ireland. Eight out of 10 people in the poll view climate change as a serious threat to human civilisation. The majority of respondents support stronger international cooperation and political action to address it.

articles.title: Paul Homewood's BBC Complaint Upheld
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: The Executive Complaints Unit upheld Paul Homewood's complaint about the BBC News article on the link between climate change and the heatwaves in America and Mexico. The original headline failed to meet the requirements for due accuracy set out in the BBC's Editorial Guidelines. The subsequent edit to the headline and the addition of a note explaining the change were sufficient for the Unit to consider the matter to have been appropriately resolved. The ECU has also laid down future guidelines for using attribution models.

articles.title: Ekiti govt pledges support for victims as rainstorm destroys over 60 houses in communities
articles.author: Premium Times
articles.summary: Ekiti govt. pledges support for victims as rainstorm destroys over 60 houses in communities. Government attributed frequent rainstorms and strong winds in Ekiti and other parts of the World to global climate change, which is caused by climate change.

articles.title: Maharashtra's Fisheries department to prepare Vision Document
articles.author: Mrityunjay Bose
articles.summary: Monsoon hit early this year and fishermen have lost 20 more days of livelihood. The department has also lost revenue due to the early monsoon, according to Rane's estimate. The fishermen have been affected by it for about a year now.

articles.title: Mozambique: Funding Cuts Threaten Support for Displaced Women Affected By Violence in Mozambique
articles.author: Isadora Zoni in Pemba
articles.summary: Conflict and extreme weather are forcing more people from their homes in northern Mozambique's Cabo Delgado Province, exposing women to sexual violence and other threats as funds to meet their needs run dry. The UNHCR-supported safe spaces provide a place where they can access psychological support, connect with others, and begin to heal.

articles.title: Climate Change May Be Increasing Cancer Risk Among Women
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: There is a significant correlation between rising temperatures and the increased prevalence and lethality of women's cancers across the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region. The study charts data spanning 1998 to 2019 from seventeen countries, including Algeria, Egypt, Iran, Saudi Arabia, and others vulnerable to the compounded effects of heat stress and ecological degradation.

articles.title: Cancer rates rose for women in some countries where extreme heat is rising, study says
articles.summary: Temperatures rose in Middle Eastern and North African countries over the last two decades. There was a small but significant increase in cancer cases and deaths among women in 17 countries, according to a new study. Climate change increases exposure to cancer risk through ultraviolet radiation and air pollutants.

articles.title: Doctors sound alarm over link between cancer explosion and crisis Trump calls a hoax
articles.author: EMILY JOSHU STERNE
articles.summary: For every 1.8 degrees Celsius temperature rise, cancer cases increased by up to 280 per 100,000 people in ovarian, breast, cervical and uterine cancers in 17 Middle Eastern countries over the last 20 years. Cancer deaths from all four cancers on average rose by 171 to 332 for each degree of temperature rise. The greatest rise in deaths was in ovarian cancer, the smallest in cervical cancer and the least in breast cancer.

articles.title: Bulkhead alternatives could reimagine a changing coast
articles.author: Ava Kocher
articles.summary: There is a 1m sea level rise expected by 2100 along the North Carolina coast. Coastal Review invites differing viewpoints on topical coastal issues. North Carolina has restricted the building of new seawalls since 2003 to protect beaches, but bulkheads against estuarine waters are ubiquitous, and the salt marshes are in danger.

articles.title: Global Warming May Boost Women's Cancer Risk
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Scientists have found that global warming in the Middle East and North Africa is making breast, ovarian, uterine, and cervical cancer more common and more deadly. Cancer prevalence and deaths rose in only six countries: Qatar, Bahrain, Jordan, Saudia Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, and Syria.

articles.title: Bushfires NT Plans Burn: Stuart Hwy Verge to Bridge Creek
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Bushfires NT volunteer brigades will be conducting road verge burning as part of the annual mitigation program. The planned burn is currently underway. The smoke from the fire may affect visibility and the firefighting crews may be working close to the roadside. The burn is located on DLI Road Verge Adelaide River Township boundary to Bridge Creek Station boundary.

articles.title: Invisible in the Exodus: How Bangladesh's Women Are Hit Hardest by Climate Migration
articles.author: Co E-EDP
articles.summary: There are projections that 13.3 million people could become internal climate migrants in Bangladesh by 2050, accounting for more than a third of South Asia's total. The World Bank's knowledge brief, 'Climate Migration and Its Impacts on Women in Bangladesh,' co-developed with the Bangladesh Institute of Development Studies (BIDS) and supported by the Geo-Enabling Initiative for Monitoring and Supervision (GEMS), explains how climate-induced migration is reshaping gender dynamics of vulnerability across Bangladesh.

articles.title: Memorial Day weekend proves Pinellas beaches have bounced back after Hurricanes Helene, Milton
articles.author: Jennifer Kveglis
articles.summary: Hurricanes Helene and Milton disturbed a beach renourishment project the shoreline was due for on its 10-year cycle. Last Fall, Hurricane Helene flooded out buildings and left behind thick mounds of sand. Rick Falkenstein's restaurant, Hurricane Seafood, was able to reopen shortly after the storms.

articles.title: Earth on Track for 2.7°C Rise, Dire Climate Outlook
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Sven Teske is the research director at the Institute for Sustainable Futures, University of Technology Sydney. The world is feeling the effects of climate change. The worst case scenario of expanded coal use, soaring emissions and a much hotter world is vanishingly unlikely. Earth is tracking towards around 2.7°C average warming by 2100.

articles.title: UNESCO Urges Australia to Protect Great Barrier Reef
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: UNESCO draft decision shows Australian and Queensland governments have much work to do to protect Great Barrier Reef. UNESCO's draft decision expressed its "utmost concern" that the outlook for the Great Barrier reef is "very poor" and it could be considered for inclusion on the World Heritage 'In Danger' list next year. UNESCO has called on Australia to set further ambitious climate targets consistent with limiting temperature increases to 1.5°C. Australia must cut climate pollution by 90% by 2035.

articles.title: What is causing the record high temperatures in the UAE?
articles.author: Daniel Bardsley
articles.summary: The UAE is experiencing record-breaking heat this month, with temperatures in excess of 50°C. The highest temperature in the month of May was 50.4°C in Abu Dhabi on Friday, while the previous day it was reported to have been 50.2°C, which is the highest for the month. The peak for May was 52°C on Al Yasat Island in 2010. This month's record temperatures come hot on the heels of the UAE recording its warmest April, with the average high last month being 42.6 °C. Climate change may be playing a role in both the UAE's and the region's escalating weather.

articles.title: As Sweihan swelters, what is causing the record high temperatures in the UAE?
articles.author: Daniel Bardsley
articles.summary: The UAE is experiencing record-breaking heat this month, with temperatures in excess of 50°C. The National Centre of Meteorology has reminded the public to drink lots of fluids, avoid direct exposure to the sun, ensure children are not left in cars and also to make sure pets have plenty to drink. This month's record temperatures come hot on the heels of the UAE recording its warmest April. The average high last month was 42.6°C and the peak for the month was 50.2°C in 2009.

articles.title: Reviving Niger Delta's Mangroves: A Natural Solution To Climate Crisis
articles.author: Leadership News
articles.summary: Mangroves are under threat in Nigeria, especially across the Niger Delta region. They act as shields against flooding, habitat for aquatic lives and natural carbon sinks that help fight climate change. The Hensard University in Toru-Orua, Bayelsa State organised a capacity building workshop for women and youths on restoring mangroves.

articles.title: Australia inundated with bogus asylum seeker claims
articles.author: Unconventional Economist
articles.summary: There are a record 2,541,651 temporary visas on issue in Australia ( excluding tourists) in the latest data from the Department of Home Affairs, according to the data from DHA. The data shows that a record number of people are applying for temporary visas.

articles.title: Minister Phillip Spotlights Climate Change And Social Vulnerability At GSIS Youth Forum
articles.author: Observer News
articles.summary: Island Youth Forum is a pre-event of the Global Sustainable Islands Summit being held in the twin-island Federation from May 27-29, 2025. The Minister of State responsible for Social Development, the Honourable Isalean Phillip, delivered the keynote address on the topic of climate change and social vulnerability.

articles.title: Humanity's great future challenge
articles.author: The Echo
articles.summary: Ken Clarke's article about climate change in the last Echo makes valuable points. Population increase is the most fearful factor in climate change. It would be easier to mitigate climate change if the population were stable or decreasing. People will have to make adaptations and sacrifices for the future, but we human beings are not good at that.

articles.title: Superheated classrooms are compromising our children's and their teachers' health
articles.author: Webmaster Nbsp
articles.summary: The ideal classroom temperature for learning and teaching is 74°F (23.3°C) in St. Vincent and the Grenadines. Excessive classroom heat negatively affects children's academic performances across all subject areas, but the impact is greatest on math and math-like subjects. For every 1°F rise in classroom temperature, there is a corresponding 1% fall in marks. Some children and teachers are at higher risk of heat-related illnesses.

articles.title: Summers in Karachi
articles.summary: Karachi's summers are becoming increasingly unbearable. There are frequent power outages, water shortages, and a lack of shaded public areas. Long-term planning is insufficient. Public awareness campaigns, the provision of cooling centres, and improvements in electricity and water infrastructure are needed. Urban greening and tree plantation drives must be prioritised to combat the urban heat island effect.

articles.title: Mark Steyn: Here's to you!
articles.author: Devvy Kidd
articles.summary: 20 delegates from the U.S. voted for the 'environmental crisis' cooked up by the communists in Moscow in 1928. Hundreds of scientists reject global warming. The American people have been brainwashed to believe one lie after another to 'save the planet'.

articles.title: Sikh food charity serves up free hot meals for flood-hit Australians
articles.author: Straits Times
articles.summary: Farmer Mark Kappa was enjoying his first hot drink in three days as he went for a walk in the Australian countryside.   He is from Ginnni, Australia, which is located in the Northern Territory. He lives with his wife and two children.

articles.title: Here's how to protect yourself and your home this fire season
articles.summary: Warmer temperatures and a drier winter mean a higher risk of wildfires this season. St. John's Regional Fire Department and the Newfoundland and Labrador Forestry Service offer some tips on how best to reduce risk of fire damage and be safe this summer.    .

articles.title: Climate swings squeeze farmers
articles.author: WRAL
articles.summary: Climate swings squeeze farmers. WRAL takes a look at some ways farmers can fight back against the changing weather patterns and climate change in the U.S. is a big problem for agriculture in our states and WRAL looks at how farmers can deal with it.

articles.title: Regional bloc warns of higher temperatures in Horn of Africa
articles.summary: At least seven countries in the Horn of Africa region are expected to record higher-than-normal temperatures between June and August. The countries are Ethiopia, Somalia, Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, and Tanzania. Some of the countries will record temperatures of over 32 degrees Celsius during the period.

articles.title: Latest Kapiti Sea Level Predictions
articles.summary: The Kapiti Coast District Council has uploaded the Waikato University De Lange research and accompanying maps onto its website. The research identifies about 40 homes in danger of sea rise, compared to thousands of homes identified in previous reports. Coastal Ratepayers United (CRU) filed a judicial review to urge the council to accept De Lange's updated coastal predictions and make the notification available on LIMs. CRU chair Salima Padamsey says climate change research is being updated constantly.

articles.title: Extreme temperatures costing Australian workforce 60.6 mln USD annually: study
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Extreme heat and cold is costing Australian workers and employers an estimated 94 million Australian dollars (60.6 million U.S. dollars) each year. The study analyzed over 2.3 million workplace injury claims from 2005 to 2018 across all Australian state capital cities. 1.66 percent of all occupational injuries and illnesses, nearly 39,000 cases, were linked to heat exposure.

articles.title: Dust storms sweep across Australia as experts warn of growing climate extremes
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: A vast dust storm moving across Australia has shrouded Sydney in a dense haze, sparking health alerts. The event is a stark reminder of Australia's vulnerability to shifting weather patterns and land degradation. The dust storm originated in drought-hit areas of western Victoria and South Australia, where dry, bare soils are vulnerable to erosion.
